item.title: Using melt and dcast in data.table
item.description: melt(data, id.vars = c("will_not_change") # Columns will remain the same, constant identifiers that all variables have associated values for measure.vars = c("converted_to_variable_value")) # Columns names go into `variable` column and values go into `values` columns # Optional -> specify column names melt(data, id.vars = c("will_not_change") measure.vars = c("converted_to_variable_value"), variable.name = "name_of_variable_column", value.name = "name_of_value_column")

item.title: Keep only complete rows with no NA values
item.description: Keep only complete rows (omit any row with NA values) dt <- dt[complete.cases(dt)] dt <- dt %>% .[complete.cases(.)]

item.title: Remove rows with all NA
item.description: Remove rows with all NA but keep any row with at least 1 observation: dt <- dt[rowSums(is.na(x)) <= 1] dt <- dt %>% .[rowSums(is.na(.)) <= 1]

item.title: Split a data.table into a list by row number
item.description: Split a data.table into a list by row. Each row element then becomes an element in the list. dt <- dt[, row_id := .I] listy <- split(dt, dt$row_id) or this may be simpler as it eliminates the requirement to create an additional column holding the row numbers. listy <- split(dt, seq(nrow(dt)))

item.title: Test if all values in column are NA
item.description: Test if all values in a column are NA. all(is.na(dt$column)) # TRUE all(is.na(c(NA, 0, NA))) # FALSE Links: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/9417391/how-to-check-if-entire-vector-has-no-values-other-than-na-or-nan-in-r
